object_name: Hanging scroll, one of a pair (right)
provenance: Azabu Museum of Art; then sold at Christie's New York, Park Avenue, Sale 9044 (AN IMPORTANT COLLECTION OF JAPANESE UKIYO-E PAINTINGS), 27 October 1998, lot 118, $4,600 to Bill Clark
text:
Jōryō’s paintings of clean-cut beauties wrapped in luxurious kimono became very fashionable, and his influence can be seen in similar paintings even today. The left scroll represents a maiden from Kyoto, troubled that the hem of her robe is blowing in the wind, while the right scroll depicts a boy sneaking a peek, as though his powers of observation have stirred a wind strong enough to pry open her kimono.

(with 2013.29.111.2)
title: Peeking Boy, from Kyoto Maiden and Peeking Boy [right]
